success-1.title: Inputs to the Change Management Process
body: Documented in a business case or project charter that covers:
- What is the project?
- Why is the project needed (issues and opportunities)?
- How will the project solve the problem or address the opportunity?
- What is the recommended solution?
- What are the risks if the issues and opportunities are not addressed?
- When will the solution be implemented?
- How much money, people and time are required to deliver the solution and realize the benefits?

success-2.title: Defining Success
body: Success includes both project objectives and organizational benefits.
The primary sponsor defines success; the change practitioner documents and socializes it.
To clarify benefits, answer:
- What is the problem or opportunity?
- If solved, what benefit(s) result?
- How will you know the benefits have been realized?

success-3.title: Project Objectives
body: Objectives describe what the project must achieve and align to organizational strategy.
Clarify by asking:
- How will the project help solve the problem or realize the opportunity?
- What will the project produce or enable?
- How will you know the objectives are achieved?

success-4.title: Adoption and Usage Objectives
body: Three people-side factors shape ROI:
- Speed of adoption
- Ultimate utilization
- Proficiency
Define each factor for your change and set measures/targets. Effective change management improves each factor.

success-5.title: Measures of Success
body: Assign quantitative indicators for every project objective and benefit.
Leverage existing metrics where possible.
Without measures, you cannot accurately assess achievement.

success-6.title: Prioritizing Objectives and Benefits
body: Most changes pursue multiple outcomes.
Prioritization helps teams focus effort and make trade-off decisions when facing scope creep, budget cuts, or delays.

success-7.title: Ownership of Objectives and Benefits
body: The primary sponsor is accountable for achieving objectives and benefits.
Large changes require delegating ownership to members of the sponsor coalition so they can lead in their domains and deliver results.

success-8.title: People Dependency of Benefits
body: Structured change management captures the people-dependent share of ROI.
Discuss with sponsors:
- What percentage of outcomes depends on employee adoption and usage?
- How much are we investing (budget, people, energy) to drive that adoption?
Use the answers to calibrate the required investment.

success-9.title: Communicating the Definition of Success
body: Prosci’s 3-Phase Process begins with defining success to anchor outcomes.
A clear definition positions change management, aligns sponsors and PMs, and supports building Awareness and Desire in ADKAR.

success-10.title: Sponsor Coalition Alignment
body: The primary sponsor leads the sponsor coalition.
Coalition strength depends on members sharing a common definition of success so they can actively drive the change together.

leadership-1.title: Primary Sponsor Authority
body: The primary sponsor authorizes the change and is accountable for realizing outcomes. Sponsorship level should match change risk.
High-risk changes call for a senior executive with authority over funding, resources, people, processes, and systems.
Effective sponsors stay active and visible, build a coalition, and communicate directly with managers and employees.

leadership-2.title: Explaining the Change
body: People want to hear what is changing, why, and the organizational benefits from the leader in charge.
Sponsors must connect the change to organizational direction and describe risks of not changing.

leadership-3.title: Organizational Vision and Strategy
body: Change projects succeed more often when the organization has a clearly defined vision and strategy.

leadership-4.title: Strategic Alignment
body: A change is aligned when success can be clearly tied to achieving the organization’s strategy.

leadership-5.title: Setting Priorities
body: When multiple initiatives run concurrently, senior leaders must prioritize to allocate limited funds and resources.
Sometimes lower-priority projects must pause so critical initiatives receive what they need to succeed.

leadership-6.title: Decision Making
body: The primary sponsor owns decisions about scope, schedule, and resources.
Every project encounters changes; sponsors need visibility to issues and must resolve them quickly.

leadership-7.title: Active and Visible Sponsorship
body: Being active and visible throughout the lifecycle is one of the sponsor’s three key roles.
Sponsors who show up consistently are seen as transparent, engaged, and committed.

leadership-8.title: Building the Sponsor Coalition
body: Leading a strong sponsor coalition is another key role.
The primary sponsor mobilizes other leaders to advocate for and lead the change in their areas—critical for enterprise changes.
The change practitioner maps the coalition and suggests actions, but the sponsor owns executing them.

leadership-9.title: Building Awareness
body: Creating awareness of the need for change is the third key sponsor role.
Impacted people expect to hear the business rationale and risks from senior leaders.
A visible sponsor legitimizes the change and signals its priority.

leadership-10.title: Reinforcing Success
body: People want success celebrated by the same leader who launched the change.
Sponsors should reinforce wins and tackle resistance to avoid the perception that adoption is optional.
